item.title: The Color of Functional Foods
item.dc:creator: chrisbellion
item.content:encoded: It's not often discussed, but sometimes the color of food can have an important function too. Anthocyanins are pigments found in plants that vary from red to blue depending upon the pH. Think of blueberries. When you use them in pancakes with baking soda (high pH) they become light blue or even greenish.  When you cook them for preserves in the presence of lemon juice (low pH) they become purple. That's anthocyanins at work. [The same trick can be done with red cabbage.  Try boiling it with a tsp of baking soda and watch it turn bright blue.] Anthocyanins are flavonoids thought to have great antioxidant value and thus are encouraged as part of a healthy diet and can also be found as supplements in pill form. While the value to humans of anthocyanins is disputed, they are just another reason to eat some of nature's most well known superfoods. Among the anthocyanin rich foods are asparagus, blueberries, cranberries and pomegranate. It's no mystery why many of the products in the functional food category focus on ingredients are already well established as highly nutritional. They are superfoods because of their inherent nutritional value. And products contain them hope to represent some of that value in their foods.  The trick is to understand exactly what value these foods have and if that value is important enough to you for you to focus on.

item.title: Is Water the First Functional Beverage?
item.dc:creator: chrisbellion
item.content:encoded: Let's face it, adding minerals and vitamins to water and claiming some curative powers is nothing new.  In fact, healthy water is probably the first functional beverage we had.  And it's no surprise that as a commercial product it's still an easy winner. For thousands of years, sources of healthy water have been prized around the world.  Some of the sources of these waters, mineral springs, became world renown "spa towns" that claimed local mineral content had the power to heal all manners of illness and thus became very popular destinations for the wealthy as well as the infirm. Many are even still very popular destinations today.  But because they were all destinations, they couldn't be fully commercialized. According to Wikipedia the first mineral water to be bottled was around 1622 at the Holy Well in Malvern, England. It was thought to be mostly for local use.  By the 1740s there were already many advertisements in England for bottled mineral water that were being sold outside of their region. The early adopters of bottled water were probably on to something.  A clean water source has always been tantamount to good health. Did these bottled minerals waters offer anything beyond not carrying pathogens?  Likely not.  But staying healthy is the purpose behind functional foods, and good water certainly helps with that.

item.title: To Everything Turm, Turm, Turm...There is a Season(ing), Turmeric
item.dc:creator: chrisbellion
item.content:encoded: It seems like the "it" ingredient changes every day. Good bye goji berry. Ba-bye açaí.  It's time for turmeric to have its turn.  Turmeric is a rhizome in the ginger family native to southwest India. It is usually found in powdered form for use as a spice. But these days you can find it in pill form, as an ingredient in smoothies and orange juice and even coffee. One of the ironies of superfoods is that they are often foods that have been for a long time known and used by many many people. Turmeric is a good example of this. It has been used for a very long time by millions of people as the spice that makes curry yellow. So it's so-called "discovery" is a bit belated, yet not unimportant. Recent studies have proven what people believed for a long time: turmeric can be very good for you.  It has been reputed to boost brain power, have anti-oxidant qualities, help to lower the risk of heart disease and to help prevent liver cirrhosis.  According to a study published in Liver International "Curcumin [a compound derived from turmeric] inhibited the development of TAA-induced liver cirrhosis mainly due to its anti-inflammatory activities". If there is even a grain of proof to all of the turmeric claims, look for it to take over the shelves of your home very soon.

item.title: What Is The Function of These Funky Spirits?
item.dc:creator: chrisbellion
item.content:encoded: Liquor.com wrote an article about 6 Wacky Spirits You Only Wish Were Available in the U.S. about wacky drinks with wacky ingredients that are available elsewhere.  After perusing the list, it seemed obvious that it was written because there was one drink on the list that they really wished was available in the US: Kierewiet Cannabis Liqueur. America's hemp-happy mania is highest now since the venerable old days of Reefer Madness. It's medicinal man! And every permutation of pot is near on the horizon. Are we going to soon find pot brownies in the functional food section of the supermarket? We're not that far off. The fact is that combining booze with bud is a very winning combination for the blogosphere. And as such, it is well-trodden ground.  See Kierewiet featured here in 2008 and here in 2011. A little more searching says maybe that was wrong. Maybe this wasn't written to be about a stoner's choice. Maybe it was written in a stoner's style - lazy, that is.  Almost all of the spirits featured here are also featured in a 2011 "Daily Mail" article entitled World's 10 Weirdest Spirits. It looks like nothing interesting has happened in the spirit world in a while. Want another buzz kill? According to this article, there is no THC in Kierewiet. So if you were looking for some of the good stuff, you just found the booze equivalent of a bag of oregano.

item.title: Conjunction Junction, What's Your Function?
item.dc:creator: chrisbellion
item.content:encoded: For some, "functional" beverages doesn't refer to an added health benefit of the beverage provided through vitamins or minerals or other enhancing ingredients. For the more literally minded in the market place, it simply refers to an improved function of the vessel that carries it.  Take the innovation by spirits brand owner The 86 Co. They asked bartenders to help them design a better bottle and they did. Before you click, be forewarned: A better bottle does not mean a bottomless supply of hooch.  That bottle has already been invented.  In this case a better bottle means a tapered body for easier grip and measuring marks on the side to help with inventory (aka, keep tabs on high-elbowed bartenders). It even has a tapered neck to "to assure consistent flow".  How do you like that?

item.title: Dysfunctional Spirits
item.dc:creator: chrisbellion
item.content:encoded: It had to happen. You know you thought of it too. Hell, you might have even tried it yourself. The good news is that you (probably) will not be arrested for it. But these guys will. Two Chinese distilleries, Guikun Alcohol Plant and the Deshun Alcohol Plant,  are being investigated for lacing baijiu they produce with Sildenafil, what is better known as Viagra.  This is not your grandfather's flavored vodka.  But it is being marketed to him. Baijiu by itself is a fragrant beverage high in alcohol that is generally distilled from sorghum, which, despite the claims of the man drinking it, can generally have the opposite effect of Viagra when consumed in large quantities.  Those who purchased this functional beverage were told that the baijiu had health-preserving qualities. Oddly, by perusing the website for a baijiu bar/baijiu distillery in Beijing called Capitol Spirits, it's easy to discover that this very thing happened another time, almost exactly one year ago, when a Chinese business man was arrested for producing more than 2,000 bottles of Viagra laced liquor.  The man who reportedly sold and gave away most of the bottles, keeping 30 bottles for himself, is currently doing hard time.

item.title: Just One More Powdered Cocktail for the Road
item.dc:creator: chrisbellion
item.content:encoded: Do you remember last spring when the TTB finally (for the second time) granted its approval to Palcohol, a powdered alcohol produced in Tempe, Arizona? It was supposed to be on the shelves by summer.  And yet, nary a flurry has his the stores. Why?  Like Luke Skyywalker lamented, it's been banned in the U.S.A. - almost. State after state has lined up pledging to not allow Palcohol or any other alcoholic powder across their borders. Some of them are Alaska, Maine, North Dakota, Vermont, Georgia and 15 others which can be found here. The reasons are the usual suspects when a new product hits the market: "People will abuse it", "Kids will have access", and a slew of other reasons that sound a lot like "I just don't understand". Despite the great momentum for a nationwide ban on powdered alcohol, a few states are stepping up in support. NJ Senator Michael Doherty wrote a Letter to the Editor explaining his vote against banning the substance in his home state. In it he said, "I voted no because I believe that the proposed ban on the sale of powdered alcohol...goes against the free market principles that have made our country great."  The home state of Palcohol too has gotten behind the brand, sort of.  Governor Ducey of Arizona vetoed a bill that would have banned it from the state calling the bill unnecessary and asked the state to regulate it like other alcoholic beverages.  The forecast isn't great right now for Palcohol, but it seems unlikely that it won't make the shelves someday.

item.title: "Pear" Pressure Can Lead to Fewer Hangovers
item.dc:creator: chrisbellion
item.content:encoded: "Come on. Have another.  Go ahead. Drink it. It will make you feel good." Pressured friend slugs glass of pear juice and smiles. He says, "Hey that was good."  They two then sit down and polish off three rounds of Tom Collins without fear of a hangover the next day. Does that scenario sounds realistic?  Well according the Australian firm the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) it's exactly what you should be doing.  They recently published research that said pears are a wonderfruit for staving off hangovers. Their work follows up on a 2012 study published in Phytotherapy Research that established that "Korean pears stimulate the two key alcohol-metabolizing enzymes". They're not quite sure how it works, but they believe that there are factors in the pears that speed up the metabolism of alcohol which also leads to lower blood alcohol levels (or BAL). They also found that this remedy had the greatest effect on the hangover symptom of "trouble concentrating".  So it's very useful for drinking on work nights! To date, their studies have focused on the Korean pear variety.  So if you binged on boscs before finishing this story, apologies. The good news is that they're good for you too; any fruit is a functional food. But you might still have a hangover. It won't be very long before some cider company is promoting a Korean pear perry (pear cider) with a stamp of approval from the CSIRO.

item.title: You Ought to Drink a Little Wine
item.dc:creator: chrisbellion
item.content:encoded: A little wine? Those were the words of St. Paul to his disciple St. Timothy.  He thought it would be good "for the sake of" his stomach.  Wine is good for you? So the bible says and it still is news. At least it's good news.  More and more ink has been spilled lately over the incredible health benefits contained within the grape skin. The main focus of these stories is a natural phenol (a chemical compound) found in the skins of some fruits called resveratrol. This compound is produced when the fruit is either damaged or attacked (by a fungus). It's a protective measure and science now believes it can protect us too. Numerous studies are ongoing, and definitive results are far off to be sure. The best we can do in the meantime is prepare for the best by drinking wine.  And should bad news befall us, at least we have wine and the good book to sooth us. Stay tuned...

item.title: A Drink That Makes You Lose Function Now Comes in a Bottle
item.dc:creator: chrisbellion
item.content:encoded: Reports of the boilermaker's death have been greatly exaggerated. The early days of the millennium gave the boilermaker a bad name - literally, the name changed from something proactive like "maker" to something destructive like "bomb", as in "Irish Car Bomb" and "Jaeger-bomb".  They were bought by the round at 10 bucks a-pop and left more booze on the bar than what was imbibed. To add insult to injury, it seemed the "bomb" part referred to the destruction of the bar's glasses used when they were slammed by the drinker in triumph as if to say, "I did it. I drank some booze with some other stuff from two glasses then I spilled a bunch and chipped the glasses a bit. Hurrah!" Gone are the days when the boilermaker was a drink of the genteel, perhaps enjoyed by two respectable ladies sharing each other's company on a balmy afternoon. Or are they? Like every other drink in this cocktail revolution in which we live, the boilermaker has been kicked up a notch.  You can now find the drink made with ingredients like sherry and amaro alongside the traditional "whiskey-back".  And now, you can even find it in a bottle. Leave it to the Germans to come up with an all-in-one container that when opened drops a smaller bottle of booze into another bottle of soft drink which then mix and can be taken as a shot.  They call this device U-Boot after the famed German submarines. In fact their tag line is "Open The Cap, Sink The U-Boot".  They feature neon flavors like Lemonade Glacier Water and Energy Cordial. Not quite the sexiness of "Jack-and-a-beer-back", hey? Glibness aside, it's clear that a lot of people will find this type of functional packaging fun and it will probably be showing up in your liquor store before you know it.

item.title: Scientists Claim They Can "Jailbreak" Yeast to Give It Any Function You Want
item.dc:creator: chrisbellion
item.content:encoded: The click-bait nature of a title on a story like this will usually tell you that you can now drink alcohol without a hangover, but the truth is much scarier.  Scientists at the University of Illinois have discovered a way to genetically engineer certain strains of commercial yeast that "have been widely used in the wine, beer, and fermentation industries."  The importance of this finding is presented by publications like EurekAlert as a gateway to being able to "reducing the toxic byproducts that cause your morning-after headache." Reducing hangovers is one-two with erection medicine as the most sought after quacksalver on Earth. But their claims go beyond reducing headaches. By being able to engineer the yeast they feel that they can boost existing compounds in a wine yeast like resveratrol, say, 10-fold. They also feel they can sub-out genes for other beneficial compounds without affecting the taste. Once they isolate the purpose of all of the genes in the yeast they're studying, the possibilities are endless. Maybe we're closer to the future than we think.

item.title: The Function of Aging Spirits in Space
item.dc:creator: chrisbellion
item.content:encoded: By now we've all heard of the many new-fangled ways of ramping up the aging process of alcoholic beverages. In general, when it comes to wine and whiskey especially, older is seen as better. To that end every effort is being explored to understand what exactly the function of aging is to the end product. One far out method is being endeavored by spirits mogul Suntory. They're sending six samples of their whiskey into space to age for at least a year to see if the zero-gravity atmosphere will offer any insight to the aging of spirits. (They'd better hope they don't encounter this guy.) Five years ago around this time, the story of "Shackleton's Whisky" was all the rage. The short of it was that a British explorer named Sir Earnest Shackleton had to abandon an expedition to the South pole in 1909, leaving behind four cases of whiskey which were rediscovered by scientists in 2006. Should the Suntory whiskey get lost in space, it would be interesting to see what future generations think of their dram.  We'll see.

item.title: Sometimes There's a Function Beyond the Function
item.dc:creator: chrisbellion
item.content:encoded: The word "whiskey" is derived from an old Gaelic term uisge beatha which literally means "water of life" (say the U and I together to get a W sound and use a hard G for a K sounds and it becomes very clear). For many a tippler that's always been a more figurative meaning than anything.  But if recent science is true, you might be able to take that claim quite literally. Whiskey is reputed to claim very high levels of a natural phenol antioxidant called ellagic acid. While it's not inherent to the whiskey per se, it's a compound commonly found in some species of oak trees. And whiskey is aged in oak barrels. So aged whiskey has very high levels of ellagic acid.  What does ellagic acid do? Glad you asked. Many people believe that the ability of ellagic acid to absorb rogue cells in the body means it has anti-cancer properties.  Furthermore, a 2001 study showed that whiskey was far less damaging on the stomach than pure ethanol, likely due to the presence of ellagic acid. While most reasonable scientists temper these claims by stating overdrinking will lead to more problems than help, this shows a dram now and then for health's sake isn't such a bad thing. Thus the functional oak barrel, used to store and age whiskey, is transforming it into a functional beverage of sorts.

item.title: Drink Wine for Brain Function
item.dc:creator: chrisbellion
item.content:encoded: It really is a superfood, and one that many will willingly imbibe.  Studies seem to come out daily on the power of wine to decrease heart disease, help lose wait, and prevent diabetes. So what can be left? Turns out that it makes you smarter too. Well maybe that's not completely accurate, but it will slow down your getting dumber. A study published in the journal Alzheimer’s & Dementia: The Journal of the Alzheimer’s Association examined the cognitive effects of the MIND diet on its participants.  According to the website "The Drinks Business", the MIND diet "is a hybrid of the Mediterranean and DASH (Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension) diets, which have both been found to also reduce the risk of cardiovascular conditions such as hypertension, heart attack and stroke." "The Drinks Business" article continued: "The study, carried out by researchers at Rush University Medical Center in Chicago and funded by The National Institute of Aging, evaluated cognitive change over a period of 4.7 years among 960 dementia-free older adults. Averaging 81.4 years in age, the participants were tested on their ability in five areas – episodic memory, working memory, semantic memory, visuospatial ability, and perceptual speed – with their diet recorded and analysed." The subjects were given a specific daily diet which included one glass of wine. The conclusions were stunning. They found that among their participants, adherence to the MIND diet "substantially slows cognitive decline with age". With the rise of cases of Alzheimer's disease, studies like this are sure to get a lot of attention. Delaying cognitive decline can lead to the delay of the onset of Alzheimer's or it's elimination all together.

item.title: Functional Food and the Sounds of Summer
item.dc:creator: chrisbellion
item.content:encoded: It's all about bugs. Is that the ingredient of now? According to Six Foods, the people behind Chirps, a chip made from protein packed cricket flour, you should be eating what bugs you. Ew.  Sorry, the idea of eating insects is always going to freak some people out. But are the health benefits worth getting over your squirmishness? Chirps claim to have 6g of protein per serving or 3x that of potato chips and 40% less fat. There probably aren't many people that think potato chips are a healthy go to for protein, so this is an odd comparison to be sure, but it's nice to know. But when compared to the protein bombs of the snack world like Quest Protein Chips (21g per serving), it's quite a bit behind. Like all odd snacks, its success is going to have to rest in its taste.  According to their Amazon reviews, they have believers. So why not try some with a side of fried tarantula and wash them down with a Cricket Cola while you're at it. It's awfully quiet in here.

item.title: Gin Ant What it Used to Be
item.dc:creator: chrisbellion
item.content:encoded: What did the Pink Panther say when he stepped on an ant? "Dead ant, dead ant, dead ant, dead ant, dead ant, dead ant, dead ant, da, da, dead ant." There is a gin made from ants.  Some of you might have stopped reading right there.  For those of you still around, here are more details: Insects in food have become quite the trend. There are cricket chips called chirps, grasshopper burritos and moth worm...well you get the picture. Most times, when you read about insects used for people food it's for the protein content.  But Anty Gin uses ants for the taste of their acid. Y'up. Anty Gin was created in a joint venture between the non-profit Nordic Food Lab of Copenhagen and Cambridge Distillery, a self-described "gin tailor". They found that red wood ants (formica rufa) produced formic acid when threatened.  Formic acid is known for its very pungent and acidic odor, so they naturally thought of adding it to gin. Actually it makes sense.  Acidic flavors are often added to gins in the form of citrus fruits.  So think of a lemon with 6 legs. Remarkably ant distillate is nothing new.  In 1671, Englishman John Ray was the first to isolate formic acid by distilling large numbers of ants. Soon thereafter, formic acid was synthesized and widely used as a preservative. And here it is again, harnessed by the English to pickle people.  Add a few ml. of this, and you'll have one hell of a Entomotini.

item.title: Functional Beverages On Tap
item.dc:creator: chrisbellion
item.content:encoded: Pay attention, Tin Man, beer may be good for your heart. A 2013 Greek study of beer drinking and its affect on important predictors of cardiovascular (CV) risk showed that the old slogan "Guinness is Good For You" made have been on to something. The study published in Nutrition tested 17 men who were non-smokers and averaged 28 years-old. They drank beer, vodka, nonalcoholic beer and water. Working under the assumption that moderate drinking could improve CV health, they wanted to test what effect beer had when compared to other alcoholic beverages.  Their conclusion stated, "Beer acutely improves parameters of arterial function and structure, in healthy non-smokers." That is very good news. If the stated goal of functional beverages is to contain some health improving quality, well then it seems  we have a winner. So if you haven't already poured yourself a pint, you may begin now.

item.title: Turmeric for Japanese Hangovers
item.dc:creator: chrisbellion
item.content:encoded: While the "it" ingredient turmeric is just starting its slow takeover of the functional food fields in America, Japan has been at it full bore for a while now. The popular functional compound found in abundance in turmeric, curcumin, is pitched in Japan as a sure-fire hangover cure that also helps the liver.  Given that description, why wouldn't you by it before a night of drinking? The most popular product is Ukon No Chikara (House the Power of Turmeric). It's a curcumin bomb featuring 30 mg of the stuff per 100 ml bottle. It's slightly viscous, cloyingly sweet and redolent of light spices. And it sells! Its popularity has led to "me too" products from Japan's biggest food companies.  Not long ago, Kirin Beverage put out Kirin Hakko Ukon, a fermented tumeric yoghurt infused with nutritional ingredients.  (Sounds like a great option for brunch before mimosas.) It might sound crazy right now, but before long you'll be chewing turmeric gum and gulping turmeric smoothies.

item.title: A Functional Beer That's Not a Beer
item.dc:creator: chrisbellion
item.content:encoded: Kirin Free known as Kirin Yasumu Hi No Alc 0.00% in Japan is a beer that's not a beer.  It's supposed to taste like beer and appeal to beer drinkers. But despite the name which translates to "Alcohol Beverage for Days Off" it also clearly says on the label that there is 0.00% alcohol in it.  This contradiction in a can is puzzling to be sure.  What's even more puzzling is that when it came out it was a huge success! Former Kirin President Senji Miyake called it a major hit in 2009 when addressing the consumers' demand for "cross-functional" beverages. What was functional about it? Kirin Free was made with Ornithine, an amino acid which has shown to have anti-fatigue properties and has also been shown to help in the treatment of liver cirrhosis. So when you want to drink beer, but are worried about the dangers of alcohol, drink a beer that's not a beer but is better for you than beer: Kirin Free.

item.title: A Functional Food for Your Next Bowl Game Party
item.dc:creator: chrisbellion
item.content:encoded: Have you ever thought that you love nachos with chicken, but you hate the bother of scooping the chicken up with the chip?  What's a person to do?  The answer is finally here:  Meat Chips. Meat Chips combine the high snackability of a corn chip with the protein packed power of chicken.  Meat Chips are chips made with meat. Meat Chips pack a whopping 21g of protein per bag and come in 4 flavors: Black Pepper, Ranch, Salsa (so you don't have to dip) and Nacho (so you don't have to even make nachos with chicken). Protein rich snacks are coming in every form imaginable now from the venerable bar, to protein popcorn to cricket cakes. There are also other competing protein chips out there. At the end of the day, your choice comes down to whether you like the product and it fits your need. If the a meat chip does it for you, then this item is perfect.

item.title: Is Guinness Stout Our First Functional Food?
item.dc:creator: chrisbellion
item.content:encoded: "Guinness is Good For You" began as a campaign for the Irish stout in 1929.  Of course the brewery (now owned by Diageo) couldn't make such a health claim today. But that doesn't mean that they can't let others make it for them. Study after study has shown that moderate drinking can reduce the incidence of cardiovascular (CV) disease. There have even been studies that have placed beer on the top of the adult potable pedestal when it comes to supporting CV health. Therefore it's no surprise that scientists have found that Guinness might actually be good for you when consumed in moderation. The general rule of thumb is darker beers are better for you. Remember that darker beer doesn't have to mean more alcohol or more bitter. It's just the color of the malted barley used to brew the beer.  Some say that darker beers (like red wines as opposed to white) have richer flavonoid content. Flavonoids are polyphenols thought to have antioxidant properties.  Darker beers have also been shown to be far richer in iron than their pale counterparts. So, while the claim that it's "good for you" might not be that far off, it's easy to prove that a pint of Guinness in your favorite pub can certainly be fun.  And fun is definitely good for you. But that's a different subject.

item.title: If Beer Smells Good, Will You Drink It?
item.dc:creator: chrisbellion
item.content:encoded: There is a problem inherent in creating nonalcoholic (NA) beers: getting beer drinkers to drink them instead of soft drinks. Most producers will argue (probably correctly) that beer drinkers not looking for alcohol will more likely drink NA beers when they taste like regular beers.  That's easier said then done. According to homebrew shop Midwest Supplies making NA beer is as easy as heating newly made beer to 175 degrees before bottling. At that temperature ethyl alcohol will burn off leaving behind the rest of the ingredients (beer). If this process sounds familiar it's because it's how distilling spirits works.  What they describe is letting the alcohol vapor escape (what a waste). In a still the vapor would be trapped and condensed to make, in this case, bierbrand, a pseudo-whiskey.  Midwest Supplies warns that this process leaves the NA beer remaining quite bitter. There's that taste problem again.  Taste tests for NA beers show that beer drinkers would never mistake them for the real thing. This problem has led researchers at the University of Valladodid to come up with an ingenious method for improving the flavor of NA beers.  Basically they took the smell of a regular beer and infused it into the NA beer.  And you know what? It worked.  According to their findings 90% of tasters chose the smell-enhanced beer over regular low-alcohol beer. And 80% of tasters chose it over NA beer. The results shouldn't be surprising.  It's fairly obvious that men will drink just about anything that smells like beer.

item.title: College and Beer Go Hand and Hand. But Collagen Beer?
item.dc:creator: chrisbellion
item.content:encoded: It wasn't long ago that collagen drinks were making headlines.  It was dubbed the latest beauty trend to come out of Asia and was quickly adopted in England. Collagen is a naturally occurring protein responsible for healthy skin. As the body ages it produces less and leads to thinner, more wrinkly skin.   The idea was that women should imbibe a drink loaded with collagen (derived from fish) which would work its way through the body ultimately enhancing her appearance. First there were many skeptics who insisted that the collagen would never make it to the skin; that it would be filtered through the liver before it ever showed any benefit. Then defenders stepped up saying that although it was filtered through the liver, the excess of collagen in the blood triggered a natural regenerative response by the body which led to desired results. Regardless of the science, it sold, and continues to sell like hot cakes, leaving women only to decide which to choose. Then the game changed again. Leave it to the Japanese to take it to a new level by creating a collagen laced beer. Japanese Booze behemoth Suntory introduced Precious, a 5% ABV beer with 2 gm of collagen aimed at women because, as they say, "Guys can tell if a girl is taking collagen or not.” That is a type of "beer" pressure heretofore unseen in the marketing world.  It essentially says that if a man does not see you drinking a collagen beer than he will know that there is no reason to be interested at all. Suntory probably doesn't realize that there already is a potion that makes woman appear prettier to men. It's called beer. And it's drunk by men. And it works really well. Functional beverages are normally thought of as non-alcoholic products, but clearly the line is being crossed more and more.  While the efficacy of a collagen laced beer is hard to imagine, it won't be long before more alcoholic beverages attempt to address pressing health concerns.

item.title: Water's Function Beyond Being Just Water
item.dc:creator: chrisbellion
item.content:encoded: Water is in for another onslaught in the functional foods world as brands continue to infuse their message into the bottle. Bai Brands, the company known for its "antioxidant-packed" cofeefruit beverages, has just launched a bottled water they call Antiwater. No, it's not a protest of H2O, rather it's an infusion of water with antioxidants they cleverly dub H2.0. It is an evolution or even an elevation of water? Bai understands that the water shelf is crowded but they told BeverageDaily.com that they believe that they will stand out because of their antioxidant levels, or as they call it "hydration with a purpose".  Carla O'Brien of Bai Brands said, "Compare Antiwater to every other water out there and there is no comparison." They are not the first brand to try to take water in a new direction recently. A water infused with an extract of coconut oil called FATwater launched earlier in the month which claims to help you hydrate quicker and burn calories. But we know this is an old story.  Healthy water claims go back centuries in the historic spa towns of Europe. Truth be told, if Ponce de Leon is still looking for his fountain of youth, he won't find it in a bottle, yet.

item.title: Gin is a Functional Spirit for a Great Functional Cocktail
item.dc:creator: chrisbellion
item.content:encoded: In this age of collagen-infused beer (which really should be called "con-fused beer") and daily updates about the benefits of resveratrol in wine, it's important to remember that one of the great health tonics of all time is the venerable Gin and Tonic. That ought to put a smile on your face. The internet is awash with stories heralding the inherent health qualities of the juniper spirit we call gin. Nearly all of the stories point to the diuretic qualities of gin, assumingly passed on from the assumed diuretic properties of the juniper berries that flavor the spirit. (It's important to note that alcohol has diuretic properties too as it speeds up the passing of water through the kidneys.) This observation has led the writers to claim that gin "fights kidney and liver disease" and gin "is good for you kidneys". While such highfalutin claims are at best hyperbolic (and at worst criminally negligent), the more cautious say that gin "makes you feel less bloated". However you slice it, a diuretic flavored diuretic will make you make water.  That's certainly a health claim to stand behind. Another common claim of gin is that it's "natural".  This is an odd one that likely comes from a misunderstanding of why the ingredients in gin are called botanicals.  Botanicals can be almost any plant at all. The plants used to flavor gin (lemon, angelica, orris root among others) for no special reason are called botanicals. Using that naming method, beer is flavored with botanicals (hops). As are spiced rums (cinnamon, nutmeg, etc.) And absinthe (wormwood, anise, fennel). Because they are called "botanicals", people feel that they are healthier than other plant ingredients. Maybe they are, maybe they aren't. But the bottom line is that they are mostly natural. And natural isn't exactly bad for you, even if their purpose is undefined. So the oddly axiomatic claim that botanicals are natural stands. Another claim of gin, or more specifically its most popular cocktail the Gin and Tonic, is that it's anti-malarial. That one is spot on.  Tonic water is made from extracts from the bark of the cinchona tree. Those extracts (quinine) have been historically shown to be extremely effective in battling malaria.  In fact, until 2006, quinine was considered a first-line treatment for malaria by the World Health Organization. Hold your horses.  Who is turning to gin because of malarial fears?  Well it does help to treat fevers and relax muscles too.  So another win for gin. The fact is that if you are looking for a drink that will help you pee and at the same time reduce your fever, and you like Gin and Tonic, this is the beverage for you. And if you're looking for a little added boost, find an old tom gin aged in oak barrels. It'll contain ellagic acid which has been shown to protect the stomach better than unaged gin.

item.title: Gin Soaked Raisins - The Spirit of a Functional Food
item.dc:creator: chrisbellion
item.content:encoded: In case you haven't heard, gin has health benefits that make it a decent diuretic, and, when combined with tonic water, terrific at fighting malaria.  But did you know that gin-soaked raisins can help fight arthritis?  This home remedy for joint pain has been around for a long time and actually has quite a few adherents. What is it? It's just what it says it is. It's so simple it's scary.  The pharmaceutical directions are as follows: Take some golden raisins; pour some gin over them; wait for the gin to evaporate; eat raisins; repeat.  Why on earth the recipe asks for you to allow the gin to evaporate (assuming they actually mean that you should let the ethyl alcohol evaporate from the gin) is unimaginable beyond that it must have been written down the first time by a teetotaler. How could this cure could have any efficacy beyond that of the effect of ethyl alcohol? But there it is asking you to remove that from the equation. So what's left? The raisins flavored with your favorite gin should be a bit bitter and mushy. And they should contain whatever health properties that golden raisin normally contain plus a light juniper flavor, which together are not necessarily a bad thing.  However, the same thing can be found by dropping raisins in a martini and fishing them out of the bottom of the glass when you're done with the drink (or before you're done with it). The word around the interwebs is that this cure was popularized by the legendary radio host Paul Harvey, who in 1994 said on his eponymous show that the practice had been around for some 20 years already.  Undoubtedly his wide audience spread the word of his recommendation high and far. But does it help?  Probably not at all (especially with the alcohol removed).  Snopes.com does a great job of discussing and debunking any possible medical benefits. Common sense should say that if raisins cannot help on their own, then they shouldn't help when flavored by anything. Common sense will not get in the way of people making money on it though.

item.title: Entropia: A Gin That Energizes Cocktails in Spain
item.dc:creator: chrisbellion
item.content:encoded: Who needs a Red Bull and vodka when you can have a gin infused with energy drink ingredients? Entropia gin from the Galicia region of gin-crazed Spain takes what is mainly a straightforward gin botanical mix and infuses the finished product with the mind-enhancing botanicals ginseng and guarana. You read that right. Those ingredients are not in a mixer, but in the gin itself. And they are not distilled in the gin, they are infused after the fact, which leaves the gin a pale brown color. ¿Por qué? It could be because they create a great flavor for the gin.  It could be that the gin makers wanted to harness the notable benefits of ginseng and guarana.  Or it could be because they are really popular ingredients right now and they thought it would look cool. Let's put the disingenuous choice number three aside for a moment and look at the ingredients in questions. Ginseng is at the top of the pyramid as far as natural ingredients are concerned having been used in Asian medicine for many millennia. It’s a food, a good luck charm, a medicine for stress, high blood pressure, libido and many other ailments - it's Latin name, panax, comes from a Greek word for "cure-all". It's the good stuff and everyone knows it. Guarana is a caffeine-rich fruit of a South American shrub which is known to be an effective stimulant and all around energy booster.  It has become very popular as a big name ingredient in almost every energy drink out there.  You might say that it is (or was) the rock star of Rockstar. By themselves, these are some pretty powerful plants.  But some say that they are even more effective in harmony. According to some health professionals like Dr. Edward R. Rosick, when ginseng and guarana are taken together they can lead to improved cognitive function. So what's that mean for Entropia? Is this a brain food? An energy drink? Is it a functional spirit? It's not likely any of those. But even if there is any benefit to adding these ingredients to their gin, they could never say so. It would be very hard for an alcoholic beverage to make what is essentially a nutritional claim. This is a case of a brand being smart enough to know that the consumer knows enough about the ingredients that they don’t have to make any claims of their own.  By now guarana and ginseng are as ubiquitous on the club and bar scene as salt and pepper are on kitchen tables.  Which brings us to choice three above. The reviews of the taste of Entropia are good but don't go very far beyond that of a standard gin profile. So this might just be a sprit hoping to cash in on its rock star ingredients.  So while they're at it, they might as well up the superfood quotient by making rock star cocktails like this one with goji berries.

item.title: Vermouth is Back; One of the World's Earliest Functional Spirits is Making a Big Comeback
item.dc:creator: chrisbellion
item.content:encoded: It was cast aside. It was left to spoil on the back shelf.  Its best friend, Gin, didn't want any part of it any more. And then suddenly, it was back.  Vermouth is making a splash on the craft spirit scene with new regional brands popping up all over the globe, along with new versions being put out by the long established brands. Vermouth, you should know, is an aromatized and fortified wine. Aromatized, in this case, means that it is flavored with various herbs and spices to have a have a pleasant smell. It is fortified with a high spirit alcohol like grappa or brandy to, well, make it stronger and thus shelf stable. The name vermouth is derived from the wine's main flavorant, wormwood (artemisia absinthium), and its history can be traced back thousands of years. For instance, in ancient Rome children were fed wormwood wine with honey as a medicine.  A medicine? Does that make vermouth a functional beverage? An argument could be made for it.  Wormwood itself has properties that are highly regarded for its use in anti-malarial drugs and have shown anti-cancer properties.  If the vermouth has a base of red wine, it could have a high quantity of resveratrol (though truthfully, normally white wine is used to make vermouth).  But wait, there's more.  The very nature of vermouth dictates that it must be made of many medicinal botanicals.  Some of them like yarrow, ginger, milk thistle, quinine, hyssop and juniper all have proven medical benefits. To date, there are no vermouths that make any direct health claims. And certainly this is not ancient Rome, so it would be difficult for an alcoholic beverage today to make a health claim.  But it's not unreasonable to think that some of these medicinal tonics will begin examining their properties for beneficial qualities. In the meantime, start trying them out and searching for your favorite. And know that as a functional spirit, vermouth's current function is to make cocktails taste better.

item.title: Cannabis Beers: "Highly" Functional Drinks
item.dc:creator: chrisbellion
item.content:encoded: Pot is legal and becoming legaler in many states across the country, man. So it's only natural that weed would spread into other industries that could take advantage of this all-time high in interest.  Take the pot edibles business. Companies like Incredibles are touting the Cannabis Cup award winning snacks infused with THC. And there are sites that rate and rank the top pot edibles in the country despite most reports saying that there's really no way of knowing how much THC the snacks contain. So you got your smoke and you got your snacks (which ironically give you and satisfy your munchies), but what do you have to wash them down? Canna-beer, of course.  Dad & Dude's Breweria out of Colorado plan to introduce to the world next month two beers laced with a non-THC cannabis extract called cannabidoil. Although the brews do not contain THC, they are purported to be the first cannabis infused beers to be legally made. Of course, illegally made cannabis beers have been made before.  There's no record of how many home brewers have experimented with reefer recipes. But for the curious here are two how-to's here and here on how it's done. Many will note that cannabis and the main flavorant of beer, hops, are cousins. So a cannabis beer shouldn't be as shocking a concoction as say a placenta smoothie. The relationship between the two plants and their familiar odors have been even explored by breweries before who created beers which were odes to the odor of marijuana like Pinner from Colorado's own Oscar's Blues and Dank IPA from Dad & Dudes. The fact remains that these "Canna-beers" (like cannabis spirits) do not contain THC and are therefore no more functional than the base beer would be.  So if it doesn't contain THC, then what is the function? Well one function it has is to get lots and lots of press.

item.title: What's Old is New. A Weed Wine for the Ages.
item.dc:creator: chrisbellion
item.content:encoded: Clever California vintners are blazing a well-trod trail that goes all the way back to ancient China. The "you put weed in it" entrepreneurial spirit that has come lock-step with the decriminalization of marijuana has creating all sorts of niche products.  But one of them, weed-wine, is nothing new. In fact it has already been around for millenia, and was well known in China as a very functional spirit. Weed-wine is, well, what it sounds like: there is weed in the wine. Cannabis is put in a barrel and aged with wine which extracts cannabinoids from the plant into the wine. The effect is supposed to be "a delicious full body buzz".  At least that's what established rock star and budding ganjapreneur Melissa Etheridge told CBS News.  Etheridge owns an exclusive line of wine tinctures, or wines infused with cannabis, which are "only available to California residents with a valid cannabis ID". They say that if you sniff around California vineyards, you'll find plenty of off-market weed-wines, some of which have been around for decades. But long before there even was a California, cannabis was a versatile and very important crop in ancient China. There is archeological evidence of the use of hemp in China for more that 12,000 years. It was used to make rope, clothing, paper, to design pottery, and of course used as medicine, in what could certainly be termed a functional spirit. As early as the 2nd century AD, a Chinese surgeon named Hua T'o is thought to have combined wine and cannabis for his patients to take as an anesthetic before surgeries (and likely thereafter as well). Which brings us back to California. When Etheridge was diagnosed with cancer in 2004, she began using marijuana for medical reasons to ease the pain of chemotherapy. She decided to keep the medicine in her life to control her stress and ease her stomach which she found to be bothered from the chemotherapy. She is the first to license a wine-weed product, but will hardly be the last.  With other potables like hemp vokda and THC beer coming to market, it's only a matter of time before pot potables becomes its own category of functional beverages.

item.title: Kickstart My Heart. Smart Bottle Proves the Revolution Will be Digitized
item.dc:creator: chrisbellion
item.content:encoded: You didn't think that the water bottle was done being innovated, did you? There is no end to the new designs and features the water bottle has taken on over the years from goat bladder bota bags to army canteens to solar powered light caps the development of water bottles has strangely followed many of our most important industrial trends. So it should be no surprise that there is a smart water bottle. (Note: it’s the bottle that's smart, not the water, unless you fill it with Smart Water. But that will probably cause the universe to end.) HidrateMe is a bottle that communicates with your phone or fitbit or whatever you will use tomorrow to communicate with things to let you know how much water you have drunk and how much more and when you should still drink.  The free app that comes with the bottle even develops a customized "hydration equation" that sets your personal "water goals". No one will buy that! They already have. The makers crowd-funded their project on Kickstarter. And of their $35,000 goal they received $627,644 from more than 8,000 backers. That's a lot of early adopter thirsty people.  According to their website, products will not start shipping until March 2016. So until then, you'll have to wait until you get thirsty to drink water.
